text: In 1919, the Garden City and Town Planning Association

text: international architectural tendencies battled for hegemony in
label: Paragraph

text: trying to shape the German built environment, cach in their own

text: image. The reault is a century of uremendously heterogencous
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the ideas of che Modern movement. especially Alvar Aalto’s or-

label: Paragraph

text: had on hit work

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: in Norway, In his buildings, date is used as it has been for more
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: of additive color, although occasionally one color is used as an
label: Paragraph

text: accent to the structure.

text: The Glacier Museum thus incorporates huilding traditions
label: Paragraph

text: trom Fehn's Nordic henrage that he cranslaces into a modernist
label: Paragraph

text: architectural language. giving the museum as well as his other

text: works. by choice of materials as well as form, a distinct identity.

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: Wahter Gropius. emigré architect, whose International Style and
label: Paragraph

text: social insight helped co define che aesthetics of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: would certamly grasp and give vital form to the 21st cenrury
label: Paragraph

text: were he alive to see it today. The strength of Gropnus's vision
label: Paragraph

text: was his humanisnc ability to comprehend the essentials of the
label: Paragraph

text: world in which he lived and to design the basic forms and meta-
label: Paragraph

text: phon that would give meaning to thote essentials,
label: Paragraph

text: tn the prewar Germany that Groptus inhabited for the firs
label: Paragraph

text: half of his life. Sigmund Freud, fellow incellectual érnigré, had
label: Paragraph

text: defined the essentials of human life as “work” and “love.” In
label: Paragraph

text: the contemporary milieu of Gropius's Bauhaus, one might make
label: Paragraph

text: the anafogy of Freud's theories of “work” ta Gropius’s theories
label: Paragraph

text: of the machine and of Freud's “love” to Gropius’ concepss of
label: Paragraph

text: the house and housing. ‘These essential chements of life were
label: Paragraph

text: given architectural expression by Gropius in the factory and in
label: Paragraph

text: the housing projects for workers, respectively. Gropius modeled
label: Paragraph

text: the total environment tor the common man, from the public
label: Paragraph

text: place in which he toiled t the private place that he came home
label: Paragraph

text: to. Thus, in the utopian new world of the decent factory environ-
label: Paragraph

text: ment and the humane housing for ins worker, Coopius, t00,
label: Caption

text: expressed modern man’s search for work and love.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: tion as Founder of the German Bauhaus and functionalist archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tect of American high modernism, bua in many ways he was a
label: Paragraph

text: complex, contradictory man. For whereas he worked passon-
label: Paragraph

text: ately for the causes of the proletariat, he conversely represented
label: Paragraph

text: the dispassionate ideal of die Newe Sachlichkeit (The New Objec-
label: Paragraph

text: tivity). Although he developed conceptual repetitive type forms
label: Paragraph

text: for architecture, the quality of his own work was highly variable.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Architect and architectural historian, China
label: Title

text: Liang Sicheng has been considered the founder of the modern
label: Paragraph

text: study of Chinese architecture, including architectural history.

text: Trained in the United States in the pracace of architecture before
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: 20thcentury Chinese of his generation to achieve signifiant
label: Paragraph

text: recognition outside of China, culminating in his involvement
label: Paragraph

text: in the planning of che United Nations headquarters, Moreover,
label: Paragraph

text: he was a central figure in the movement to find and identify
label: Paragraph

text: premodem Chinese buildings and bring them inte the global
label: Paragraph

text: study of architecture. Liang saw some of his goals for China's
label: Paragraph

text: buildings —and for China as defined by her buildings—come
label: Paragraph

text: ty pass. but others were thwarted by the political chaos that
label: Paragraph

text: plagued every decade of his life.
label: Paragraph

text: Liang Sicheng was born into China's privileged, educated

label: Paragraph

text: reform movement. Liang’s decision to become an architect was

label: Paragraph

text: sallaborator, wsually executing the architectural drawings for
label: Paragraph

text: their projects. Liang, Lin, and at leau 16 other Chinese students,
label: Paragraph

text: had chosen the Pennaylvania School of Architecture because of
label: Paragraph

text: the reputation of Paul Cree (1876-1945), Prior ta thei return
label: Paragraph

text: in 1928 to China, Liang and Lin worked in Cret’s Philadelphia
label: Paragraph

text: office, and he spent a year at the Harvard School of Design.
label: Paragraph

text: Once home. Liang was charged with founding a departnicnt
label: Paragraph

text: of architecture at Nurtheast University in Shenyang (Mukden),
label: Paragraph

text: Manchuria. The curriculum wat based on Cret’s Beaux-Arts
label: Paragraph

text: model.

label: Paragraph

text: University of Pennsylvania established a firm that immediately

label: Paragraph

text: cate for the preservanion of premodern archstecture at a time
label: Paragraph

text: when most of it was being demolished. All ¢his came tu an cad
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: ing locals about old structures and soeking buildings whose
label: Paragraph

text: ames he had found in historical documents. The work war
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: During the interwar years (1927.42), Libera sought the sup
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: performance including key ergonomic meawees for kitchen,

text: manuscripr Lt tecnica funzsonale dell abstacione (1943-46).
label: Caption

text: However, Libera’s legacy in the annab of 20th-cencury archi-
label: Paragraph

text: cocture is, most notably, the result of his unequivocal commit
label: Paragraph

text: ment co the development of an Italian language of Mudern archi
label: Paragraph

text: tecture. Throughout his catecr, Libera advocated the cadnal
label: Paragraph

text: transformation of Italian building practices. In 1927, while still
label: Paragraph

text: a studene at the Schoel uf Architecture in Rome, he joined the
label: Paragraph

text: ranks of Gruppo 7 and helped champion the tenets of Sealian
label: Paragraph

text: Rationalism. With Milanese collaborators Giuseppe ‘Terragni,
label: Paragraph

text: Gino Pollini, and Luigi Figini, Libera promoted the emergence
label: Paragraph

text: of an entirely new culture of architectural making. Aware of
label: Paragraph

text: transformatians in the material, social, and programmatic condi-
label: Paragraph

text: tions of daily life chroughout Western Europe, Libera called for
label: Paragraph

text: the development of a coneemporary language of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: figuration expressive of such tranwuemations. The appearance
label: Paragraph

text: of new buikling technologics such as ranforced concrete, steel.
label: Paragraph

text: and glass necessitated a parallel tnvention in the nature of archi.
label: Paragraph

text: tectural forms. As such, the Ratiunalist credo was centered on
label: Paragraph

text: the absolute rejection of ail forms of Neoclassicism, including
label: Paragraph

text: those of the Novecente Movement: a post-World War | move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment that promoted a renewal of Italian architecture via the
label: Paragraph

text: stylized representation of select architectural motifs.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Ennque del Moral was a leading figure in the first generation

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the enormous needs of a socicty attempting to reconstruct itself
label: Paragraph

text: along more egalitarian lines, With classmates Juan Gorman,
label: Paragraph

text: Alvaro Aburo, and Juan Legarreta, he read Le Corbusier's works
label: Paragraph

text: and interpreted them to fit a Mexican reality. In sum, dicy
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the answer was structural.

label: Paragraph

text: facilities.

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: shades of the surings and the woodwinds and the bras.”
label: Paragraph

text: well recerved by Bennett and his fellow bankers. In the design,
